abstract: As Israeli forces pound Gaza, the area where Palestinians can seek shelter is shrinking, raising concerns that they could be forced into Egypt.
lead_paragraph: The last point of refuge for Palestinians fleeing from Israel’s relentless siege of Gaza is collapsing under the weight of tens of thousands of people seeking food and shelter, stirring fears of a potential mass displacement into Egypt, United Nations officials warned on Sunday.
headline: Gazans Mass at Border for Safety, but Find Only More Peril
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Egypt;Refugees and Displaced Persons;Rafah (Gaza Strip);Palestinians;Palestinian Authority;Hamas;Gaza Strip;Israel;Qatar;International Relations;Sinai Peninsula (Egypt)

abstract: Claudine Gay, Harvard’s president, faced rising pressure after her answers to questions about antisemitism. Some faculty members signed a petition supporting her.
lead_paragraph: The president of Harvard University, Claudine Gay, faced escalating pressure on Sunday to resign as prominent alumni, donors and politicians called for her ouster. But a group of faculty members rallied to support her, arguing that she was being railroaded for a moment of poorly worded remarks about antisemitism.
headline: As Harvard President Faces Pressure to Resign, Some Faculty Show Support
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Colleges and Universities;Harvard University;Gay, Claudine;Stefanik, Elise;Magill, Elizabeth;Massachusetts Institute of Technology;University of Pennsylvania;ACADEMIC FREEDOM;Freedom of Speech and Expression;Anti-Semitism

abstract: Department stores have been a frequent target of takeover attempts by investors looking to take advantage of prime real estate.

keywords: Shopping and Retail;E-Commerce;Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures;Real Estate (Commercial);Brigade Capital Management LP;Macy's Inc

abstract: Tammy Lacher Scully’s adult son disappeared 18 months ago from a psychiatric hospital in Bangor. It has fallen on her to keep the search going.

headline: In Maine, a Mother’s Lonely Quest for Her Missing Son
keywords: Missing Persons;Mental Health and Disorders;Content Type: Personal Profile;Bangor (Me);Lacher, Graham;Schizophrenia;Autism;audio-neutral-informative

abstract: A musical about seven autistic young adults, played by seven autistic young actors, breaks new ground on Broadway.

abstract: No matter how dark the days, we can find light in our own hearts, and we can be one another’s light.
lead_paragraph: The mornings are dark, the late afternoons are dusky, and before we finish making dinner, the daylight is gone. As we approach the darkest days of the year, we’re confronted with the darkness of wars, a dysfunctional government, fentanyl deaths, mass shootings and reports of refugees crawling through the Darién Gap or floundering in small boats in the Mediterranean. And we cannot avoid the tragedy of climate change with its droughts, floods, fires and hurricanes. Indeed, the world is pummeled with misfortune.
headline: Finding Light in Winter
keywords: Winter (Season);Disasters and Emergencies

abstract: Covering long Covid solidified my view that science is not the objective, neutral force that it is often said to be.
lead_paragraph: In the early months of the Covid-19 pandemic, when many people who are now still sick were first infected, the common wisdom was that the coronavirus either sent you to an intensive care unit or, more commonly, caused mild symptoms that resolved after two weeks. But when my sister-in-law got infected in March 2020, she was still burning with fever after three weeks, then six, then more. In this newspaper and elsewhere, young and formerly healthy people shared stories about surviving but not recovering. When I interviewed scientists and clinicians about these lingering symptoms in May, most expressed surprise. “That’s unusual,” one said.
headline: Reporting on Long Covid Taught Me to Be a Better Journalist
keywords: Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Long Covid;Chronic Fatigue Syndrome;Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns;Chronic Condition (Health);News and News Media

abstract: In a new memoir, the filmmaker and playwright shares his opinions on Hollywood past and present.

headline: David Mamet, a.k.a. ‘Embittered Dave,’ Would Like a Word
keywords: Books and Literature;Mamet, David;Content Type: Personal Profile;Everywhere an Oink Oink: An Embittered, Dyspeptic, and Accurate Report of Forty Years in Hollywood (Book);Writing and Writers

abstract: As part of its New York City Center season, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presents premieres by Amy Hall Garner and Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish.
lead_paragraph: The dancers don’t so much step onto the stage in Amy Hall Garner’s “Century” as burst within it like a glitter bomb, showering the space in pink and gold. For “Century,” her first work for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, performed on Friday at New York City Center, it’s clear that Garner doesn’t merely know a party when she sees one — she knows how to dream one up. A metallic curtain hangs in the back as dancers, looking like fuchsia flowers, vibrate from their shoulders to their feet like petals caught in a breeze.

abstract: On “Pink Friday 2,” the rapper remains a star navigating hip-hop on sometimes untested terms. But even as she’s receded from the center of the genre, her lessons remain.
lead_paragraph: Before the arrival of Nicki Minaj in the late 2000s, only a handful of female rappers had ever released platinum solo albums: Lauryn Hill, Missy Elliott, Lil’ Kim, Foxy Brown, Da Brat, Eve. Despite their innovations and artistry — or maybe because of them — the genre had narrow expectations and accommodations for the expression of women, and often pitted them against each other, as if the space for anyone but men was zero-sum.
headline: Nicki Minaj, a Role Model for Herself, and Others
keywords: Rap and Hip-Hop;Minaj, Nicki

abstract: ‘The Taste of Things’ with Juliette Binoche, a nonalcoholic sparkler in a magnum, holiday stollens and more food news.
lead_paragraph: “The Taste of Things,” a French food film, will be shown in theaters this week in order to qualify for the Oscars and to make you really, really hungry. The 145-minute film by Tran An Hung, starring Juliette Binoche and Benoit Magimel, is based on the 1920 novel “The Life and Passion of Dodin-Bouffant, Gourmet” by Marcel Rouff, inspired by the French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin, who gave his name to a cheese and a cake. The film is set at a modest château in the Loire region, the centerpiece of which is the robust kitchen where Dodin-Bouffant and his cook, Eugénie, prepare sumptuous meal after meal for Dodin’s small coterie of gourmands, as their own love story gently simmers. The pièce de résistance is a classic pot-au-feu. The chef Pierre Gagnaire was the consultant for the cooking, and in an interview in New York he said “everything is real; there was no faking.” (Not quite: There was backup gas fuel for the wood-burning stove, and small quail stood in for ortolans, a delicacy that is illegal.) He said the stars knew how to cook and “jumped right in.” Ms. Binoche told me that the food “haute cuisine but not pretentious.”  From Dec. 13 through 20, there will be a menu at Frenchette, in TriBeCa, with three dishes from “The Taste of Things”: a ballotine of duck, pot-au-feu and baked Alaska ($90 or à la carte).
headline: No Ortolans Were Hurt During the Making of This Film
keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks;Food;Movies

abstract: Monika Sprüth and Philomene Magers built one of the art world’s most powerful businesses by not following conventional wisdom.
lead_paragraph: For several weeks this past autumn, a fashionably dressed woman could be seen in the window of a London art gallery stooping to pick up a half-dozen designer shopping bags. A digital print on a mirror made by the artist Sylvie Fleury, the woman was permanently frozen in the act, her bare midriff impervious to the rain outside. A collection of real bags on the floor before her doubled the optical illusion for passers-by, who might have been carrying their own bags from the nearby Versace or Dolce & Gabbana stores. But the gallery, Sprüth Magers, is not the kind of place where most people can casually drop in and buy something; the artworks sold there fetch prices in the tens to the hundreds of thousands. If Fleury’s work poked fun at the view that art is just a commodity, it was also a nostalgic reflection on the moment the empty shopping bags were first shown by the gallery, in 1991 — a time when neither she nor her dealers could have afforded a permanent storefront in Mayfair.
headline: The Gallery That Has Never Lost an Artist
keywords: Art;Spruth Magers (Berlin, Germany, Gallery);Berlin (Germany);Holzer, Jenny;Kruger, Barbara;Imhof, Anne

abstract: A fight over an expiring national security law descended into disorder on the eve of an expected vote on rival bills to reauthorize and overhaul it.
lead_paragraph: The House scrapped votes on rival bills late Monday that would narrow the scope of a powerful surveillance tool after an ugly fight broke out among Republicans, likely punting until next year on plans to renew but also limit an expiring wiretapping law at the heart of the program.
headline: House Plan to Vote on Extension of Disputed Surveillance Law Collapses
keywords: Surveillance of Citizens by Government;United States Politics and Government;Espionage and Intelligence Services;Privacy;Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA);Federal Bureau of Investigation;House Committee on Intelligence;House Committee on the Judiciary;House of Representatives;Senate;Johnson, Mike (1972- )

abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the dangers of noise in daily life, and the health risks excessive noise can pose. Then, they will document the noise levels in their own communities.
lead_paragraph: Featured article: “Noise Could Take Years Off Your Life. Here’s Why.”
headline: Lesson Plan: ‘Noise Could Take Years Off Your Life. Here’s Why.’

abstract: Plus, the debate over who’s a “colonizer.”
lead_paragraph: Top Israeli officials have warned that increased Hezbollah attacks on northern Israel carried out from Lebanon could prompt a powerful response, as Israeli troops waged street battles against Hamas in Gaza.
headline: Tuesday Briefing: An Israeli Warning to Hezbollah

abstract: Starting on the stove, then finishing in a low oven, ensures rosy meat with charred crusts, Genevieve Ko writes.
lead_paragraph: There’s an undeniable urge to roar — or at least growl — when setting a thick steak into a ripping hot pan. Hearing the hard hiss of the sizzling fat is satisfaction enough, but then the smell of charred meat follows fast, and it’s pure pleasure from there.
headline: The Best Way to Cook Steak for Holiday Parties
keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks;Recipes;Beef;Holidays and Special Occasions;Parties (Social);Christmas;internal-open-access

abstract: After 14 years, a new interview suggests this dispute may keep giving us new chapters.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr. Joan Crawford and Bette Davis. Optimus Prime and Megatron.
headline: Bad Blood: A Timeline of the Swift-West-Kardashian Feud
keywords: Swift, Taylor;West, Kanye;Kardashian, Kim;Celebrities;Pop and Rock Music;Rap and Hip-Hop;MTV Video Music Awards;Famous (Song);1989 (Album);The Life of Pablo (Album);Reputation (Album)

abstract: Cold, wet weather combined with a lack of clean water, toilets and food have fueled a spike in respiratory, stomach and other ailments, and the sick are left struggling to recover, health officials say.
lead_paragraph: Infectious diseases are ravaging the population of Gaza, health officials and aid organizations said on Monday, citing cold, wet weather; overcrowding in shelters; scarce food; dirty water; and little medicine.
headline: ‘We Are All Sick’: Infectious Diseases Spread Across Gaza
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Palestinians;Refugees and Displaced Persons;World Health Organization;Gaza Strip;Shortages;Disease Rates;Israel

abstract: The Biden administration said it would be asking questions about reports of Israel illegally using white phosphorus in Lebanon in October. Israel denied the claims.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Monday that it is looking into reports by Amnesty International and The Washington Post that Israel used white phosphorus supplied by the United States in violation of international law.
headline: U.S. Raises Concern Over Israel’s Possible Use of U.S.-Supplied White Phosphorus
keywords: Israel;Gaza Strip;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Kirby, John F;AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL;Washington Post;White Phosphorus;Israel-Gaza War (2023- )

abstract: The country’s lower house of Parliament unexpectedly passed a motion to reject a government immigration reform bill, leaving its future uncertain.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France suffered an unexpected setback on Monday as lawmakers brought his government’s immigration overhaul bill to a screeching halt, casting fresh doubts on his ability to get key legislation through Parliament.
headline: Macron Suffers Surprise Setback Over Immigration in France
keywords: France;Macron, Emmanuel (1977- );Immigration and Emigration;Darmanin, Gerald;Le Pen, Marine;National Rally (France);Politics and Government;Republicans, The (France);La Republique en Marche

abstract: Give us your best advice.
lead_paragraph: Every day in The Evening newsletter, we try to bring to readers a collection of stories, recipes and things to do at the end of the day that will help them wind down. Now, as we head into the busy holiday season, we’re looking for advice. We’re asking readers: Do you have a unique way of unwinding during the holidays?
headline: How Do You Unwind During the Holidays?
keywords: internal-reader-callout

abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky arrived in Washington at a critical moment, both on the battlefield and on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: American and Ukrainian military leaders are searching for a new strategy that they can begin executing early next year to revive Kyiv’s fortunes and flagging support for the country’s war against Russia, according to U.S. and Ukrainian officials.
headline: U.S. and Ukraine Search for a New Strategy After Failed Counteroffensive
keywords: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);United States International Relations;United States Defense and Military Forces;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Ukraine;Zelensky, Volodymyr;Crimea (Ukraine);Odessa (Ukraine);Robotyne (Ukraine);Foreign Aid

abstract: Firefighters found no victims after searching the debris left by the corner of the building that collapsed. Two people had minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters said they had searched the 12-foot-tall pile of debris left by the collapse of a seven-story building in the Bronx on Monday afternoon, and found that no one had died or been severely injured.
headline: No Deaths Reported After 7-Story Bronx Apartment Partially Collapses
keywords: Accidents and Safety;Buildings (Structures);Morris Heights (Bronx, NY);Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Buildings Department (NYC)

abstract: Global leaders and especially the U.S. government must understand we cannot save lives in Gaza under these conditions.
lead_paragraph: We are no strangers to human suffering — to conflict, to natural disasters, to some of the world’s largest and gravest catastrophes. We were there when fighting erupted in Khartoum, Sudan. As bombs rained down on Ukraine. When earthquakes leveled southern Turkey and northern Syria. As the Horn of Africa faced its worst drought in years. The list goes on.
headline: We Are No Strangers to Human Suffering, but We’ve Seen Nothing Like the Siege of Gaza
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Gaza Strip;Israel;Humanitarian Aid;Civilian Casualties;United States International Relations;Palestinians;Shortages

abstract: Israeli forces were engaged in intense battles on Monday in Khan Younis, Jabaliya and Shajaiye.
lead_paragraph: With Israel pressing its offensive in Gaza, its forces were engaged in intense battles on Monday in three parts of the strip where Israeli officials believe Hamas militants still have strongholds.
headline: A Closer Look at Three Hamas Strongholds Targeted by Israel
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Hamas;Khan Younis (Gaza Strip);Jabaliya Refugee Camp (Gaza Strip)

abstract: Dr. Gay is the first Black president and second woman to lead Harvard. She faced calls for her removal over her testimony on antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: The president of Harvard, Claudine Gay, will remain in her job, the university announced on Tuesday, despite demands for her resignation because of her testimony in a congressional hearing on campus antisemitism.
headline: What to Know About Claudine Gay, Harvard’s Embattled President
keywords: Colleges and Universities;Anti-Semitism;Black People;Blacks;Jews and Judaism;Harvard Crimson;Gay, Claudine;Kornbluth, Sally A;Magill, Elizabeth;Pritzker, Penny

abstract: Tyler Anderson of Dover was jailed and the authorities seized firearms after tracking the threatening texts to his phone and home address, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities arrested a New Hampshire man, charging him with threatening to kill Vivek Ramaswamy and his supporters, the Justice Department said on Monday.
headline: Man Accused of Sending Death Threats to Ramaswamy Is Arrested in New Hampshire
keywords: Presidential Election of 2024;Republican Party;Threats and Threatening Messages;Ramaswamy, Vivek (1985- )

abstract: Also, Trump’s immunity argument heads to the Supreme Court. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: At Harvard, students, faculty, alumni and donors debated today over the future of the school’s leadership. Claudine Gay, the university’s president, was facing calls to resign after widely criticized comments she made last week about antisemitism on campus.
headline: Elite Universities Face Turmoil Over Antisemitism Concerns

abstract: Two Georgia election workers are seeking as much as $43 million for false assertions from Rudolph Giuliani that they had sought to swing the 2020 outcome against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s lawyer told jurors on Monday that the tens of millions of dollars in damages two Georgia election workers are seeking from him in a defamation suit “will be the end of Mr. Giuliani,” likening an award of that scale to a civil death penalty.
headline: In Court With the Women He Defamed, Giuliani Faces Millions in Damages
keywords: Giuliani, Rudolph W;Presidential Election of 2020;Freeman, Ruby;Moss, Shaye;Howell, Beryl A;Trump, Donald J;Libel and Slander;Compensation for Damages (Law);Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)

abstract: In 1999, a news assistant’s number crunching revealed that The Times had gotten ahead of itself.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Dec. 12, The New York Times will print its 60,000th issue.
headline: With Issue No. 60,000, One Correction Comes to Mind

abstract: After customers’ belongings were on the trucks, the shape-shifting Brooklyn company would demand more money to unload them, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Any New Yorker who has ever hired movers has experienced the transient terror of putting all one’s belongings into a moving truck, sweating out the precarious hours poised between one apartment and another, calling neither home.
headline: Want Your Couch Back? Pay Up, Said Movers Who Ran Ransom Scheme

abstract: The wife of the Labour leader Neil Kinnock, she carved her own leftist identity with a seat in the European Parliament and as a British government minister.
lead_paragraph: Glenys Kinnock, a former European lawmaker and British government minister who helped secure for women a central role in the continent’s politics, died on Dec. 3 at her home in London. She was 79.
headline: Glenys Kinnock, Political Force in Britain and Europe, Dies at 79
keywords: Kinnock, Glenys;Politics and Government;International Relations;Women and Girls;Labour Party (Great Britain);Kinnock, Neil;Deaths (Obituaries);Great Britain
